conclusion: Points A, B, and C form an equilateral triangle with equal magnitude like charges at A and B.
Electric field due to point charges is given by E = k q/r^2.
The center O of an equilateral triangle is equidistant from all vertices, distance is s√3/3.
The electric field contributions from charges at A and B cancel out at O.
Electric potential due to a point charge q at a distance r is V = k q/r.
Potential at O due to charges at A and B is V_AB = 2kq/(s√3/3).
An equal-magnitude opposite-sign charge (-q) is placed at point C.
Charge at C produces an electric field at O opposite to the original field contributions.
Resultant electric field at O is due to the charge at C.
Potential at O due to charge at C is V_C = -kq/(s√3/3).
Total potential at O is V = V_AB + V_C.
Magnitude of electric field at O is E = kq/(s√3/3)^2.
Electric potential at O is the sum of potentials due to charges at A, B, and C.
